comments.author: Daniel Sand

comments.text:
0:43- debate over you stupid bitch. 'You're Muslim, why did you write a 
book about the founder of Christianity?'. What a foolish question. Islam 
holds respect and follows the teachings of all of prophets. From Jesus, to 
Moses, to Ishmael and Muhammad (Issa, Moussa, Ismail and Mhamad). Islam 
teaches that Jesus was one of the greatest prophets to ever live and that 
he should be respected and honoured. Islam is all about prophetic respect 
and fully acknowledges, accepts and rejoices the work Jesus did (blessings 
be upon him). It is just a matter of uneducation and stereotypes.﻿
comments.author: Michael Hadj

comments.text:
Also, I think it could possibly be the worst commentary of an interview 
ever. Your frantic tone is annoying and obnoxious, but I see that's your 
thing. Good luck with that. In the end, anyone who decided to get a job 
writing about the history of religion, all religions, but themselves 
attached their soul to just one of those religions... it's blatantly 
obvious that bias would be ingrained in any such resulting work. That 
should be obvious. Just because he SAYS there is no bias, doesn't mean we 
need to swallow his words. Just because he has PHD in his name, doesn't 
mean we need to put aside the fact that his deepest belief and values in 
this world  align to JUST ONE of the religions in the scope of religions he 
writes about. He should write about something that doesn't conflict with 
his FAITH - which as we all know can make people have the strongest agenda 
of any agendas. So now you're feeling a bit stupid aren't you TYT. It's 
okay, don't give up just because you got this one wrong.﻿
comments.author: chaiTV

comments.text:
+chaiTV While I agree with you on the annoying tone of Cenk, that's 
obviously his style so love it or hate it that's how he is, it's up to the 
audience to decide whether they want to watch him. But Reza is a scholar, 
an expert on religions who himself has converted two times, born a Muslim, 
converted to Christianity and then back again to Islam, so he doesn't 
really seem as a biased person to me.
Also one of the point TYT tried to get across is that biased people can't 
comprehend someone doing an unbiased work, I'm not saying that anyone can 
be a hundred percent unbiased but being a little biased doesn't take away 
your credibility, because by that logic no work ever done by anyone has any 
credibility. Reza is as qualified as any other expert and historian to talk 
about this topic and write a book about it and every other scholar has the 
right to agree or disagree with it, but the only thing she was trying to do 
was blatantly trying to make him look unqualified to write a book about 
"religion" which is his "field" of study, that's what he does, studying 
religion.
comments.author: Behrad Hemati

comments.text: +chaiTV BRAVO!! You nailed it!!!
comments.author: mholub

comments.text:
Don't get too excited. "Faith" isn't compatible with history, with historic 
facts. I'd prefer to hear about the history of religion from scholars who 
don't have a particular faith, or worship a particular god. It's like a 
conflict of interest otherwise when they write books purporting to be works 
of history. Don't kid yourself that this guy's work is not influenced or 
distorted by his own faith-based religious agenda.﻿
comments.author: chaiTV

comments.author: MyDamnBlog MyDamnVlog

comments.text:
I don't get it. He said it's not about Christianity but about Jesus. How 
can you seperate the two? What's he using for subject material? Outside the 
Bible there's very little written documentation about Christ. Even Roman 
documents reveal very little, not even his crucifixion is documented, and 
the Romans were known for their efficiency on writing everything down.﻿

comments.author: slapmyfunkybass

comments.text:
+sydspurs "He clearly said in interview that he has written book looking at 
Jesus as a man and a historical figure who created a political movement 
which then transformed after his death into a religion..."

Which he conveniently leaves out that all of his ideas in the book are 
derived from sociological concepts, not historical ones. He uses the Bible 
and other writings, none of which are contemporary, to try to draw a 
sociological picture of what the life of Jesus was like.

Aslan can write whatever he wants, I just don't see why he's being 
intentionally misleading unless he feels that if he's honest that the book 
is sociological and not necessarily historical that it won't sell as many 
copies.
comments.author: Will, "The Truth is hard to believe for some"

comments.text:
+Will, "The Truth is hard to believe for some" He clearly said in interview 
that he has written book looking at Jesus as a man and a historical figure 
who created a political movement which then transformed after his death 
into a religion...

In that context, a Phd in sociology can write something on a Jesus as a man 
& his influence on social life. 
So ,just dont try to confuse word against another word. Look at the context 
of his explanation in the original interview
comments.author: sydspurs

comments.author: bloodandwinearered

comments.text:
i don't see anything wrong... the first qns that she posed was a pretty 
interesting one which i would have also liked to know the motivation behind 
writing the book. In fact most term papers published by academics have a 
section called "motivation" where they talk about their inspiration which 
drove them to write the paper. Then the other questions/criticisms were 
just taken off from other people and the author had a chance to clarify 
them on national television (in fact which i thought was a good 
opportunity) but he just kept saying he's a PHD.... ﻿
comments.author: TToTToTT

comments.text:
Now while you do raise a valid point about an interviewer asking about a 
writers motivation as legitimate line of inquiry it doesnt apply here.  The 
reason being that the question was not asked in a neutral way of an 
interviewer trying to learn more information....the questioning was framed 
in such a way that it would discredit the interviewee ( i.e. why would a 
MUSLIM want to write about ......).  As such Aslan's response was merely 
the best way to handle such a loaded line of questioning
comments.author: MrJpc1234

comments.text:

anybody involved in religions are lied to
comments.author: sunn moon

comments.text:
She had one point which essentially was: why would he write a book about 
Jesus if he's a Muslim?. How is the answer he gave, 'It's my job' avoiding 
the question. She was probably told by the producers at Fox to follow a 
certain line of questioning. But if you're a good journalist you have to 
adapt to what someone's saying. If you think she did a good job, you're an 
idiot.
comments.author: Faith Vs Evidence

comments.text:
+Frank Holland
It is a lie. UCSB offers 3 history degrees and 1 religious study degree in 
their Graduate program, none of which have anything to do with sociology.

The PhD in Sociology is a separate degree and his specialization is in the *sociology 
of religion* not an interdisciplinary *history of religion* as you might 
suggest.

UCSB's description of Sociology is "Sociology is the systematic study of 
social life" which fits perfectly with how Reza actually writes. He writes 
according to the Bible and other non-canonized writings about Jesus in his 
book *Zealot*. He doesn't focus on actually historically verifiable claims 
and makes a lot of *sociological conjectures*, which, while they may not be 
wrong, are not necessarily fitting to be called history (honestly I'm 
surprised that anyone with a PhD can honestly believe in fairy tales, but 
there are a handful for sure).

If you wish to actually review the Degree programs of UCSB, where Aslan got 
his PhD, you can check their website:
http://my.sa.ucsb.edu/Catalog/Current/GraduateEducation/GraduateDegrees.aspx
comments.author: Will, "The Truth is hard to believe for some"

comments.text:
as long as it involves arguing over the internet, it would be a specialty 
of sociology.

comments.text:

comments.author: Frank Holland

comments.text:

Aslan blatantly lied about his credentials. His PhD is in Sociology, not

Anyways, Alsan just dodged the question. He could have just answered the

turned the question into something bigger than it was.
